articles.title: Scientists turn grapevine waste into clear, strong films that vanish in days
articles.summary: Amid growing concerns over plastic waste and microplastics, researchers are turning agricultural leftovers into biodegradable packaging. Using cellulose extracted from unlikely sources, including grapevine canes, they have created strong, transparent films that break down in just 17 days without leaving harmful residue.
articles.content:
The need for biodegradable packaging material has never been higher.

Currently, most packaging is "single use" and is made with plastic materials, derived from nonrenewable sources like crude oil that take hundreds of years to decompose in the environment. On top of this, only 9% of plastic is recycled. This has resulted in the formation of floating piles of plastic garbage in the ocean, called the "Great Pacific Garbage Patch."

But maybe even more concerning is the discovery of micro- and nano-plastics in the environment. Research has found that plastic breaks down into tiny particles, which are being ingested or inhaled by both humans and animals, and are found literally everywhere, including in the human body -- according to recent research studies. Worse, little is known about the long-term health effects of microplastics.

Srinivas Janaswamy is an associate professor in South Dakota State University's Department of Dairy and Food Science. His research has focused on developing value-added products through biowaste and agricultural byproducts. One of the overarching goals of Janaswamy's research is to tackle the plastic waste crisis.

Perhaps the biggest contributor to plastic waste, at least in the United States, is plastic bags, the kind found at most retail stores. These bags, while sometimes recycled, are often only used once and can be found littered throughout the environment.

To address this problem, Janaswamy is working toward developing a plastic-like bag that will decompose in the environment.

"That is my dream," Janaswamy said.

The key ingredient to Janaswamy's work? Cellulose. This biopolymer is the most abundant organic substance on Earth and is found, primarily, in the cell walls of plants. Cellulose, thanks to strong hydrogen bonds and a chain of glucose molecules, gives plants structural strength and rigidity along with other biopolymers such as mannan, xylose, hemicellulose and lignin.

Humans have long used cellulose to create products. Cotton, the material used to make a majority of the world's clothing, is primarily composed of cellulose. Wood is rich in cellulose as well.

In previous research, Janaswamy has extracted cellulose from agricultural products like avocado peels, soyhulls, alfalfa, switchgrass, spent coffee grounds, corncob and banana peels. He uses the extracted cellulose to develop films -- materials that look and feel similar to traditional plastic wrapping.

"By extracting cellulose from agricultural products, value-added products can be created," Janaswamy said.

Each of Janaswamy's films has different characteristics and properties. Some are more transparent than others. Some are stronger. But thanks to a unique collaboration with a fellow SDSU faculty member, Janaswamy may have created his best value-added product yet.

Grapevine canes

Janaswamy had just finished presenting "Ag Biomass - A Holy Grail to Clean up the Plastic Mess" at SDSU's Celebration of Faculty Excellence when he was approached by Anne Fennell, a Distinguished Professor in the Department of Agronomy, Horticulture and Plant Science and fellow College of Agriculture, Food and Environmental Sciences faculty member

After listening to Janaswamy's presentation, Fennell became interested in the research and had an idea. A leading researcher in the study of grapevines, she knew that grapevine canes -- the woody plant material that grapes grow on -- were rich in cellulose. She also knew that grapevine canes were abundant and had limited use after harvest.

"Every year we prune the majority of yearly biomass off the vine," Fennell said. "The pruned canes are either mowed over, composted and reapplied to the soil, or burned in some areas. Research in Australia showed that prunings could be removed from the field in alternate years without effecting soil health. My thought was why not use this for value added films. Several of the materials that Janaswamy previously used had a high-water content, in contrast the winter pruning yields a cellulose-dense material with low water content, making them an abundant ideal material to work with."

Fennell's idea led to a collaboration, and soon Janaswamy was extracting cellulose -- which looks almost like cotton -- from the canes of grapevines. The resulting films were eye-opening.

According to a recent study published in the academic journal Sustainable Food Technology, Janaswamy's grapevine cane films are transparent and strong and biodegrade within 17 days in the soil -- leaving behind no harmful residue.

"High transmittance in packaging films enhances product visibility, making them more attractive to consumers and facilitating easy quality inspection without the need for unsealing," Janaswamy said. "These films demonstrate outstanding potential for food packaging applications."

The grapevine canes were harvested from SDSU's research vineyard. The research team, which includes doctoral candidates Sandeep Paudel and Sumi Regmi, and Sajal Bhattarai, an SDSU graduate and a doctoral candidate at Purdue University, followed a published protocol in developing the films, which includes drying and grinding the canes and extracting the cellulosic residue. The residue was then solubilized and cast onto glass plates to create the films.

Testing revealed the grapevine cane-derived films were actually stronger than traditional plastic bags -- in terms of tensile strength.

"Using underutilized grapevine prunings as a cellulose source for packaging films enhances waste management in the field and addresses the global issue of plastic pollution," Janaswamy said. "Developing eco-friendly films from grapevine cellulose represents a practical approach to sustainability, helping to conserve the environment and its resources and contributing to the circular bioeconomy."

The results of this work move Janaswamy one step closer to his dream of developing a bag made from a plastic-like material that will quickly decompose in the environment.

Funding for this research was provided by the U.S. Department of Agriculture's National Institute of Food and Agriculture and the National Science Foundation. This original story was authored by Addison DeHaven, South Dakota State University.

articles.personality_title: Scientists create strong, clear packaging films from grapevine waste that disappear in days
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Most packaging today is made from plastic that takes hundreds of years to break down. This plastic waste often ends up polluting oceans and the environment. Tiny pieces of plastic, called microplastics, have also been found inside animals and humans, raising health concerns.

**What happened** – Researchers at South Dakota State University developed clear, strong films using cellulose extracted from grapevine canes, the woody parts left over after grape harvests. These films look like plastic but break down completely in soil within 17 days without leaving harmful residue. The grapevine waste used is usually composted or burned, so this gives it a new useful purpose.

**Impact** – These new films are stronger than regular plastic bags and transparent, which makes them good for food packaging. Using grapevine waste helps reduce plastic pollution and adds value to leftover plant material that was not used before. It is a practical step toward creating packaging that won’t harm the environment and can disappear quickly.

**What's next step** – The research team plans to keep improving these biodegradable films and work toward making bags that look and feel like plastic but fully decompose after use. This could help reduce the large amount of plastic waste from single-use bags.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists turned grapevine leftovers into strong, clear packaging films that vanish in just over two weeks, offering a promising alternative to plastic waste.

articles.personality_title_es: Científicos crean films de embalaje fuertes y transparentes a partir de desechos de vid que desaparecen en días
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La mayoría de los empaques actuales están hechos de plástico que tarda cientos de años en descomponerse. Estos desechos plásticos contaminan los océanos y el medio ambiente. También se han encontrado pequeñas partículas de plástico, llamadas microplásticos, dentro de animales y humanos, lo que genera preocupaciones de salud.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad Estatal de Dakota del Sur desarrollaron películas claras y fuertes usando celulosa extraída de sarmientos de vid, las partes leñosas que quedan después de la cosecha de uvas. Estas películas parecen plástico pero se descomponen completamente en el suelo en 17 días sin dejar residuos dañinos. Los desechos de vid que se usaron normalmente se compostan o queman, dándoles un nuevo uso.

**Impacto** – Estas nuevas películas son más fuertes que las bolsas plásticas comunes y transparentes, lo que las hace buenas para empaques de alimentos. Usar desechos de vid ayuda a reducir la contaminación plástica y da valor a residuos vegetales poco usados antes. Es un paso práctico para crear empaques que no dañen el medio ambiente y desaparezcan rápido.

**Próximo paso** – El equipo de investigación planea seguir mejorando estas películas biodegradables y crear bolsas que parezcan plástico pero se descompongan completamente después de usarse. Esto podría ayudar a reducir la gran cantidad de basura plástica de bolsas de un solo uso.

**Frase clave** – Científicos convirtieron desechos de vid en películas de embalaje fuertes y transparentes que desaparecen en poco más de dos semanas, ofreciendo una alternativa prometedora a los desechos plásticos.

articles.personality_title: New iron-based catalyst improves clean fuel cell technology without precious metals
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Fuel cells are devices that turn hydrogen into electricity without pollution. They usually need expensive metals like platinum to work well. Finding cheaper and effective alternatives has been a big challenge for scientists.

**What happened** – Researchers have created a new catalyst made from iron and nitrogen on curved carbon supports. This catalyst contains tiny single iron atoms spread out on a special carbon surface shaped with many small bumps. This design helps the catalyst work very well in proton-exchange membrane fuel cells, which are a common type of fuel cell.

**Impact** – This new iron-based catalyst works almost as well as platinum but does not use any precious metals. Because iron is much cheaper and more common than platinum, this breakthrough could make fuel cells more affordable and easier to produce on a large scale. It also helps reduce the reliance on rare metals, which can be costly and hard to find.

**What's next step** – Scientists will continue testing this catalyst to improve its durability and performance in real-world fuel cells. They will also explore ways to produce it in larger amounts. This could lead to cleaner, more affordable energy solutions for vehicles and other uses.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new iron-based catalyst shows promise as a cheaper and efficient alternative to precious metals in clean fuel cell technology.

articles.title: A hidden fuel source beneath the Midwest? Scientists are investigating.
articles.summary:
About a billion years ago, the United States was nearly ripped in half. Magma bubbled up as the Earth’s crust stretched thin somewhere around Michigan, nearly creating a new sea. Evidence of that scar, called the Midcontinent Rift, now curls around the upper Midwest, stretching from Ontario all the way down to Wichita, Kansas. Today, it’s the deepest failed rift in the world — and a 1,200-mile mining hotspot, known for its stores of copper and nickel.

Researchers believe the area may also be home to large hydrogen deposits. They are starting to think that places like the Midcontinent Rift can provide the world with enough naturally-occurring hydrogen to decarbonize the technologies that rely on the element.

That matters because, even though hydrogen is the most abundant element in the universe, it’s also one of the most difficult to capture in its pure form.
articles.content:
About a billion years ago, the United States was nearly ripped in half. Magma bubbled up as the Earth’s crust stretched thin somewhere around Michigan, nearly creating a new sea. Evidence of that scar, called the Midcontinent Rift, now curls around the upper Midwest, stretching from Ontario all the way down to Wichita, Kansas. Today, it’s the deepest failed rift in the world — and a 1,200-mile mining hotspot, known for its stores of copper and nickel.

Researchers believe the area may also be home to large hydrogen deposits. That matters because, even though hydrogen is the most abundant element in the universe, it’s also one of the most difficult to capture in its pure form. Hydrogen is tiny, with an atomic radius of about 53 trillionths of a meter, and as the lightest element it’s able to slip through even the smallest cracks.

These qualities make hydrogen expensive to produce and difficult to transport, which is a shame because the clean-burning fuel could be key for decarbonizing heavy industries like trucking, shipping, and aviation, where batteries are unlikely to provide the necessary power. If we want to continue to feed the world’s growing population, we probably need a lot more hydrogen at the ready as well. Ammonia, which is used to make fertilizer, requires an enormous amount of the element.

The U.S. currently produces about 10 million metric tons of hydrogen a year, almost all of which is created with fossil fuels and then used in refineries and ammonia plants. Most efforts to change that so far have revolved around so-called green hydrogen, in which hydrogen is ripped from water molecules in an extremely energy-intensive process called electrolysis. (The “green” in green hydrogen means that the electrolysis is powered by renewable energy.)

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

The Biden administration set out to make the green hydrogen industry more lucrative by getting Congress to pass tax credits that would pay producers $3 per kilogram of hydrogen. But when Republicans took control of Congress this year, they arranged for a phaseout of those tax credits by 2028, rather than 2033, part of a broader assault on funding for renewable energy. It’s unclear if green hydrogen producers will find a path to profitable operation anytime soon.

“If you look at the wind and solar industry, it took decades for the cost to come down,” Aaron Bergman, a fellow at Resources for the Future, a nonprofit focused on energy and the environment, told the Financial Times. “The hydrogen industry has not had that time.”

But that may all be rendered moot if it turns out that, after all, places like the Midcontinent Rift can provide the world with enough naturally-occurring hydrogen to decarbonize the technologies that rely on the element. For the first time, researchers are starting to think that might be possible.

For years, scientists believed it was impossible for hydrogen to accumulate in significant deposits. “It tends to leak through almost everything, and it’s very reactive,” said Arnout Everts, a geoscientist with the Hydrogen Science Coalition, a volunteer group of scientists, academics, and engineers who formed to provide resources about hydrogen’s role in the energy transition. “And microbes love it. Therefore, the thought was always that it was virtually impossible to trap and preserve hydrogen in the crust of the Earth.”

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

In 2007, a Malian businessman and oil magnate named Aliou Diallo discovered an enormous reservoir of nearly pure hydrogen, which now powers the village of Bourakebougou. When Diallo and his team reported the discovery in the International Journal of Hydrogen in 2018, it kicked off a rush to identify and exploit the resource. At this point, roughly 40 companies are searching for what’s now being called natural or “white” hydrogen. Within the past year, major corporations like Rio Tinto and BP have joined the crush; in January, the U.S. Geological Service, or USGS, released the first map of potential hydrogen deposits across the United States.

Natural hydrogen is created when water reacts with iron-rich rock like olivine; a process called serpentization releases hydrogen gas as a byproduct. Assuming the surrounding rock is well sealed enough to serve as a reservoir, a large deposit of hydrogen begins to accumulate. All along the Midcontinent Rift, startups are beginning to drill for the gas, hoping to unleash a functionally endless source of clean energy. (While oil and gas take millions of years to form, hydrogen is created constantly by water and rock.) In a 2024 paper, USGS scientists Geoff Ellis and Sarah Gelman estimate that if even a small portion of the global hydrogen reserve is extracted, it could meet projected clean hydrogen needs for roughly 200 years.

“I definitely think that the potential is there,” said Ellis. “We just don’t know whether we can economically find it and produce it, but the potential is absolutely there. … I’ve been surprised at how quickly this has really taken up on the commercial side, just the number of companies that have jumped into this [field] that, to me, is still very much a research kind of question.” Pure, or close to pure, hydrogen deposits like the one in Mali could be rare, and the energy required to separate the gas from other gases could increase costs precipitously.

A recent report from the Royal Society, a U.K.-based research institute, echoed Ellis’ caution, stating that although natural hydrogen deposits could be “a game changer,” it’s still too soon to bank on them.

For now, at least, that isn’t stopping dozens of companies from trying.

articles.summary:
Copernicus soars into new heights with the launch of Sentinel-5A
ldhoop
Wed, 13/08/2025 - 15:30


Ariane62, carrying the Copernicus EU Sentinel-5A & MetOp-SG A1 to a Sun-Synchronous Orbit at an altitude of around 800 km.
Following the launch of Copernicus Sentinel-4A last month, the European Union successfully launched the Copernicus Sentinel-5A to further monitor air quality and emissions around the world. 
The satellite lifted off from the Europe’s Spaceport in Kourou, French Guiana at 02:37am (CEST) onboard Ariane 62 rocket and sent its first signal to Earth at 4:47 am. The launch is a result of seamless cooperation with trusted partners, the European Space Agency (ESA), EUMETSAT and Arianespace. 
Once calibrated, Copernicus Sentinel-5A will be orbiting the Earth every 100 minutes, to deliver data on air pollutants and other atmospheric trace gases daily, around the world. 
Access to frequent, authoritative data directly support EU policies in the areas of pollution reduction and air quality management (e.g. EU Methane Strategy, EU Ambient Air Directive, Zero Pollution Action Plan). 
The Sentinel-5 mission together with the geostationary Sentinel-4 and the upcoming CO2M mission secure Copernicus as one of the most advanced Earth Observation systems in the world when it comes to atmosphere monitoring. With the launch of the Copernicus Sentinel-5 mission the EU also cements its position as space power and global leader in EO data provision.

articles.content:
Copernicus soars into new heights with the launch of Sentinel-5A

Wed, 13/08/2025 - 12:00

Ariane62, carrying the Copernicus EU Sentinel-5A & MetOp-SG A1 to a Sun-Synchronous Orbit at an altitude of around 800 km.

Following the launch of Copernicus Sentinel-4A last month, the European Union successfully launched the Copernicus Sentinel-5A to further monitor air quality and emissions around the world.

The satellite lifted off from the Europe’s Spaceport in Kourou, French Guiana at 02:37am (CEST) onboard Ariane 62 rocket and sent its first signal to Earth at 4:47 am. The launch is a result of seamless cooperation with trusted partners, the European Space Agency (ESA), EUMETSAT and Arianespace.

Once calibrated, Copernicus Sentinel-5A will be orbiting the Earth every 100 minutes, to deliver data on air pollutants and other atmospheric trace gases daily, around the world.

Access to frequent, authoritative data directly support EU policies in the areas of pollution reduction and air quality management (e.g. EU Methane Strategy, EU Ambient Air Directive, Zero Pollution Action Plan).

The Sentinel-5 mission together with the geostationary Sentinel-4 and the upcoming CO2M mission secure Copernicus as one of the most advanced Earth Observation systems in the world when it comes to atmosphere monitoring. With the launch of the Copernicus Sentinel-5 mission the EU also cements its position as space power and global leader in EO data provision.

Did you miss the launch? We got a recap for you!

articles.personality_title: EU launches Sentinel-5A satellite to improve global air quality monitoring
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union runs a program called Copernicus that uses satellites to watch Earth’s environment. Recently, it launched a new satellite to help track air pollution and gases in the atmosphere.

**What happened** – On August 13, 2025, the Copernicus Sentinel-5A satellite was launched into space from Europe’s Spaceport in French Guiana. It was carried by an Ariane 62 rocket and reached an orbit about 800 kilometers above Earth. The satellite sent its first signal to Earth about two hours after launch. This launch followed the recent launch of another satellite, Sentinel-4A, and involved teamwork between the European Space Agency, EUMETSAT, and Arianespace.

**Impact** – Once it starts working fully, Sentinel-5A will circle the Earth every 100 minutes, collecting daily data on air pollution and gases like methane. This information helps the EU enforce important rules to reduce pollution and improve air quality. Together with Sentinel-4 and future missions, Sentinel-5A makes Copernicus one of the best systems in the world for watching the atmosphere. It also shows the EU’s strong role in space technology and environmental monitoring.

**What’s next step** – The satellite will be carefully adjusted and tested before it begins sending regular data. Scientists and policymakers will use this information to better understand pollution patterns and support efforts to protect the environment and public health.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The launch of Sentinel-5A strengthens global efforts to monitor air quality and supports the EU’s leadership in using space technology for environmental protection.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’UE lance le satellite Sentinel-5A pour mieux surveiller la qualité de l’air dans le monde
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Union européenne gère un programme appelé Copernicus qui utilise des satellites pour observer l’environnement terrestre. Récemment, elle a lancé un nouveau satellite pour suivre la pollution de l’air et les gaz dans l’atmosphère.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 13 août 2025, le satellite Copernicus Sentinel-5A a été lancé depuis le Centre Spatial Européen en Guyane française. Il a été transporté par une fusée Ariane 62 et a atteint une orbite à environ 800 kilomètres au-dessus de la Terre. Le satellite a envoyé son premier signal environ deux heures après le lancement. Ce lancement suit celui récent du satellite Sentinel-4A et a été réalisé grâce à la coopération entre l’Agence spatiale européenne, EUMETSAT et Arianespace.

**Impact** – Une fois opérationnel, Sentinel-5A fera le tour de la Terre toutes les 100 minutes pour collecter chaque jour des données sur la pollution de l’air et des gaz comme le méthane. Ces informations aident l’UE à appliquer des règles importantes pour réduire la pollution et améliorer la qualité de l’air. Avec Sentinel-4 et les futures missions, Sentinel-5A fait de Copernicus l’un des meilleurs systèmes au monde pour surveiller l’atmosphère. Cela montre aussi le rôle fort de l’UE en technologie spatiale et observation environnementale.

**Prochaine étape** – Le satellite sera ajusté et testé avant de commencer à envoyer des données régulières. Les scientifiques et décideurs utiliseront ces informations pour mieux comprendre la pollution et soutenir la protection de l’environnement et de la santé publique.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Le lancement de Sentinel-5A renforce les efforts mondiaux pour surveiller la qualité de l’air et confirme le leadership de l’UE dans l’utilisation de la technologie spatiale pour protéger l’environnement.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE lanza el satélite Sentinel-5A para mejorar la monitorización de la calidad del aire global
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea tiene un programa llamado Copernicus que usa satélites para observar el medio ambiente de la Tierra. Recientemente, lanzó un nuevo satélite para controlar la contaminación del aire y los gases en la atmósfera.

**Qué pasó** – El 13 de agosto de 2025, el satélite Copernicus Sentinel-5A fue lanzado desde el Puerto Espacial Europeo en Guayana Francesa. Fue llevado por un cohete Ariane 62 y alcanzó una órbita a unos 800 kilómetros sobre la Tierra. El satélite envió su primera señal a la Tierra aproximadamente dos horas después del lanzamiento. Este lanzamiento siguió al reciente lanzamiento del satélite Sentinel-4A y fue posible gracias a la cooperación entre la Agencia Espacial Europea, EUMETSAT y Arianespace.

**Impacto** – Cuando funcione completamente, Sentinel-5A dará la vuelta a la Tierra cada 100 minutos, recogiendo datos diarios sobre la contaminación del aire y gases como el metano. Esta información ayuda a la UE a aplicar reglas importantes para reducir la contaminación y mejorar la calidad del aire. Junto con Sentinel-4 y futuras misiones, Sentinel-5A convierte a Copernicus en uno de los mejores sistemas del mundo para vigilar la atmósfera. También muestra el papel fuerte de la UE en tecnología espacial y monitoreo ambiental.

**Próximo paso** – El satélite será ajustado y probado antes de comenzar a enviar datos regulares. Científicos y responsables políticos usarán esta información para entender mejor la contaminación y apoyar la protección del medio ambiente y la salud pública.

**Resumen en una frase** – El lanzamiento de Sentinel-5A fortalece los esfuerzos globales para monitorear la calidad del aire y apoya el liderazgo de la UE en el uso de tecnología espacial para proteger el medio ambiente.
